title: 107_hr2787
content: The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 (42 U.S.C. 9858 et seq.) is amended by this Act. The purpose and findings of the Act are outlined in Section 2. Congress finds that two-thirds of mothers with children under 6 years old are in the workforce, over 10 percent of young children have disabilities (with higher rates in low-income communities), and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act mandates early intervention and special education preschool services. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act mandates early intervention services for infants and toddlers in a natural environment, and special education preschool services in the least restrictive environment with nondisabled peers. The General Accounting Office reports limited availability of infant care, care for special needs children, and care during nonstandard hours. The General Accounting Office reports limited availability of infant care, care for special needs children, and care during nonstandard hours, especially in low-income communities. Children with disabilities or special health care needs face barriers in accessing child care programs due to myths, stereotypes, and staff lacking knowledge about disabilities. The purpose of this Act is to increase the supply of quality child care for children with disabilities, as availability of care during nonstandard hours is limited, especially in low-income communities. Children with disabilities face barriers in accessing child care programs due to myths, stereotypes, and lack of staff training. SEC. 3. Amends Section 658E(c) to include families with children with disabilities. SEC. 4. Focuses on activities to improve the quality of child care. Section 658G (42 U.S.C. 9858e) is amended to include activities for children with disabilities, requiring states to allocate at least 5 percent of funds for this purpose. Section 658G (42 U.S.C. 9858e) is amended to include activities for children with disabilities, mandating states to allocate a minimum of 5 percent of funds for enhancing child care availability for children with disabilities through specified activities. The amendment to Section 658G mandates states to allocate funds for activities aimed at increasing quality child care for children with disabilities, including training and technical assistance for child care providers, licensing agencies, and parents. Training and technical assistance provided for child care providers, state licensing agencies, and parents to ensure proper implementation of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The curr_chunk focuses on collaborating to ensure appropriate implementation of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. It includes technical assistance for child care providers to better include children with disabilities in child care settings. The curr_chunk provides training for child care directors and staff on assistive technology for children with special needs and disabilities, as well as leadership skills development for directors to operate inclusive child care programs. The curr_chunk focuses on training child care directors and staff in the use of assistive technology for children with special needs and disabilities, as well as developing leadership skills for directors to run inclusive child care programs. The curr_chunk focuses on operating inclusive child care programs, including leadership skills in financial development, program development, parent education, and community development. It also provides assistance to State and local child care resource and referral agencies on compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, as well as grants for recruitment and retention of qualified staff. The curr_chunk focuses on grants for recruitment and retention of qualified staff in child care, including scholarships for staff to obtain degrees. Grants are provided for child care staff to obtain degrees in child development, including scholarships and salary increases. Grants and low-interest loans are provided by the Secretary to public agencies for certain child care programs. The Secretary provides grants and low-interest loans to public agencies and nonprofit organizations for projects that increase the availability of inclusive child care programs, child care for infants, and child care during evenings and weekends to support child development. SEC. 5. REPORTS. Amends Section 658K(a)(1)(B)(iii) by adding "disability status" to the reporting requirements. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. Section 658P (42 U.S.C. 9858n) is amended to include definitions for "child with a disability" and "inclusive child care program" in accordance with the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The term "inclusive child care program" is defined as a program that serves both children with disabilities and children without disabilities together, with no more than 50 percent of the children enrolled being children with disabilities.
